HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MARCH 9, 1956

NEWS-LETTER

New Sheath-And-Shafters
Initiated; Elections Shortly
Scabbard and Blade, the ROTC
honorary society, recently initiated 25 cadets, according to Richard Small, chairman of the initiations.
Officers of the society will be
elected within the next few weeks,
and the report of an evaluation
committee will be submitted.
Small stated, "A committee has
been appointed to investigate the
areas in which the society can be
of some service to Johns Hopkins.
We feel that participation in university affairs is an obligation df
our membership in Scabbard and
Blade."
The 25 new members are John
Abrams, Tom Brimer, Jim Buddo,
Tom Cox, Ken Daub, Tom Edmonds, Bob Edwards, Eugene
Ewachiw, John Fleischman, John
Gilbert, John Hanst, John Hughes
and Roger Kane.
Also, Henry Kayser, Lew Kirby,
Russ Marcuri, Ray May, Dick
Mercer, Lew Miller, Sid Miller,
Bill Mouring, Martin Rosensweig,
Otto Schroeder, Bill Teso, and
Howard Wisch. Bob Freeman was
pledge master of the group.

Student Council
Any undergraduate student
wishing to run for class or Student Council office must submit
his name, post-office box number, and class to P.O. Box 1048,
for approval of the Student
Election Committee, befo're 4
p.m., March 19.

Iliology Club
The Undergraduate Biology
Club will sponsor a guided tour
of the University of Maryland's
School of Medicine and Hospital next Friday. Those interested should sign up in the
dormitory post office; the
group will meet at 12:30 p.m.
in the main lounge of the
dormitory.

OPPORTUNITIES FOR ENGINEERS AND METALLURGISTS

Who will help
Hamilton Standard Division
Gabriella?
United Aircraft Corporation
Gabriella is six, the oldest of three
children. She never slept in a bed. She
goes to school because she gets one
free meal a day. She has no others.
She never owned a toy. Home is a hut,
9x12. The walls are of cardboard in
spots where the logs have rotted away.
The floor is earthen ... there are no
facilities. Gabriella's parents survived
the war in Italy, but now there is no
employment. Their hearts are torn,
for they cannot help their child ...
not even comb her hair ... they do
not own a comb. Gabriella's hunger is
unappeased, her misery deep. She cannot smile. Help to this family means
hope instead of despair ... a chance
to live ... a bulwark against destructive ideologies. Won't you help her
and her weary parents or other distressed children ... many without
one or both parents? They look to
you who can actively participate in
establishing world understanding.

00*

Carnegie And The Vandals
The other day some one out outlined to us a possible partial solution to one of the more teasing Homewood paradoxes,
one with which the Student Council is currently wrestling.
The paradox is this: given the assumption that Hopkins
men are communally obligated to act as "gentlemen" and
that therefore they need be curbed with no stated restrictions, what is to be done when occasional abuses of this
absolute liberty tend to create for the outside world the impression that the Hopkins man is not indeed a "gentleman,"
but an unregenerate slob? (Examples: sacking the ROTC
building, some events at fraternity houses, the "brawl"
aspects of some of the gym dances).
The solution suggested to us might be summed up descriptively as "moral suasion." Someone is, let us say, very
offensively and actively blotto at one of the rush dances.
Things are going rapidly downhill. It is then the obligation
of any nearby Student Council member to approach, and
attempt to ameliorate the situation, possibly by •pointing
out that this is conduct prejudicial to the good name of a
"select community of gentlemen and scholars."
Yet it seems to us that it is in the true meaning of this
phrase that the heart of the paradox lies. The Hopkins man
is "select," all right, but only intellectually select; otherwise, he comes from a thousand different environments, each
with its own shade of thinking conduct-wise, each drawing
the line at a different place. Some of us don't drink, others
stop at the happy stage, others foggily call for tomato juice
the next morning. And in such a diversified milieu, who is
to say that any approach is wrong? If there are no stated
limitations, isn't judging our conduct our business?

Of course this is not the whole story. The people we are
with have an important influence on our actions; the trouble
is, group pressure can work both ways, depending on the
situation at the moment. Another point: the campus leaders who are to do the "persuading" we have mentioned, are
leaders because of their disinclination to be a bastard about
things. (There is an old News-Letter proverb: "Nice guys
finish last—except when entry representatives are being
elected.") The phrase "knock it off" carries a certain stigma,
even among gentlemen and scholars.
What it boils down to is this: "moral suasion" can
work—indeed, already does work—up to a point; but it is
as optimistic as it is unfair, in a situation where the standards are left to the individual, to expect it to obviate all
bad publicity for the University, even with all the good
will in the world. If the Hopkins man is to be left free
to develop, it must be expected that there will be development at all levels.

The quickest and most obvious
way to do this is to make money.
This makes people, especially his
boss, think he is EFFICIENT. Who
would suspect that it is not efficiency, but done at the expense of
the quality of the food? However,
if he does just make ends meet,
is there any reason to believe that

make money and be efficient or'

Well, John, it's hard to define the difference in a way that
will satisfy everybody, because one always finds a lot of overlapping between research and development work. But most
people agree that there are differences, especially in time sequence.Research work comes first, because one of its main objectives is to establish or discover new scientific facts that will
supply the foundation for new industrial developments. In
other .words, research men seek new knowledge about matter, generally working with small quantities of it.
Development work comes later, and Du Pout has two main
types. First, there is new process development. Here scientists
and engineers modify, streamline, and augment the findings
of research so that new chemical products can be profitably
made on a large scale—or existing products can be made by
newer and more efficient methods. Pilot-plant and semi-works
operations are usually included under this heading.
Second, an important kind of development work is directed
toward improvement of existing processes and products. Here
the men study how to obtain yield increases, utilize by-products,increase outputs,and solve sales service problems as they
arise. This may require considerable research, and that brings
us back to the overlapping I previously mentioned.
There are genuine differences, John, but a good deal of
similarity,too—especiallyin the constant need for imagination
and creative effort. I think you'll find that research and development work are equally challenging and rewarding at
Du Pont.

John B.Aaron worked for Du Pont as a summer
laboratory assistant even before he graduated from
Princeton with a B.S. in 1940. After military service he
obtained an M.S.Ch.E. from M.I.T. and returned to
Du Pont in 1947. Over the years he has had many opportunities to observe Du Pont research and development
work. Today John is process and methods supervisor at
the Philadelphia Plant of Du Pont's Fabrics and Finishes Department.

Picked as the dark horse to repeat last year's showing and to
take the match, the Hopkins fencing team travels to Lehigh University tomorrow to compete in
the big event of the season, the
Middle Atlantic Championships.
Five other schools will particiPate in the event. They include
Stephens Institute of Technology,
Mulenberg College, Temple University, Lehigh University, and
Haverford College.
Each school will be represented
by a six-man
team, two men in
each weapon
division instead of
the usual
three. John Forte and
Dick .leckman,
last year's chamPions, will represent the Blue Jays
in the
sabre and will be out to
repeat last year's showing and
bring another championship
back
to Homewood.
Everett Fences
Dick
Everett gets the nod in the
foil Match,
and Tom Feher will
fence in the epee event. Coach
Cal Schlick stated that they are
both Young
and inexperienced,

but they have shown so much improvement up to date, that they
could both easily go all the way.
Al Rose will definitely fence in
the Middle Atlantics. However.
Schlick is undecided whether to
use him in the foil or the epee.
If he fences in the foil event, then
Mark Zequeira will be the second
man on the epee team. But if
Rose competes in the epee, Fred
Rosenblum will get the nod in the
foil.
Schlick commented, "On the
basis of their showing against us,
Temple and Lehigh will be the
teams to beat. Every man will
have to fence eleven bouts instead
of the usual three. He will have to
face his own team mate first and
then each man from each of the
other schools in the other ten
bouts."
'Supreme Effort'
"Everyone on the team will
have to be geared to fence these
eleven bouts. We have a fairly
good chance if everyone is at his
peak, but it is going to take a

A Favorite Rondez Wu for Hopkins Men

supreme effort." The varsity mentor also stated that he spent the
entire week getting the team into
top shape, hoping to outlast the
other teams.
"Before the Middle Atlantics,
we must finish an incomplete
match against Temple. The score
now stands 13-9 in Temple's
favor. It will take five successive
victories in five epee bouts to give
the Blue Jays a win," stated
Schlick.
Last Saturday, the Hopkins fencers played host to Lehigh in their
last match of the regular season
and dropped a; close 15-12 decision
in what Coach Schlick called "the
best fencing he's seen this season."
The Blue Jays led most of the

way and were ahead 11-8 late in
the match. "However the visitors
lived up to their reputation of being a late starting team and came
through in the end." Schlick
stated,"we had them, but couldn't
hold them. Our inexperience
showed in the last key bouts."
Foil Loses 6-3
Hopkins dropped the foil by a
6-3 score. Dick Everett turned in
two wins, 5-3 and 5-2, and dropped one, 4-5. Howie Pierce was
defeated in all three of his bouts,
4-5, 2-5, and 3-5. Fred Rosenblum
turned in a 5-1 triumph, but lost
two, 2-5 and 3-5.
Cal Schlick, in summing up the
result of the meet, said, "Last
Saturday, the whole team fenced
very well.

Bridgers Expresses Desire
For Distance Performer
•Looking for a top-notch long distance runner, Coach John Bridgers sent his track prospects
through their initial drills last
week in preparation for a triangular practice meet with Towson and Western Maryland on
March 23.
The Jay Coach feels that the
long distance events are the
team's weakest department. Occasionally C o-c aptain Sam
Wright, primarily a field man,
was sent to the post in the distance events last season in an
attempt to alleviate this problem. However, Bridgers is looking to Co-captain Jack Sutherland, Bill Willoughby, and Jack

Lettermen Bolster
Varsity Ball Team
With six returning regulars as
a nucleus, the Blue Jay diamond
squad began workouts Wednesday
under the direction of Coach Ross
Sachs.
Last year's top batsman, Outfielder Howard Alfandre, is returning as is the entire 1955 infield of John Newton at first base,
Jerry Carr at second, Charley
Wyble at third, and Loren Cox at
shortstop.
Walt Radek is the only returning mouncisman, but Sachs expects to gain some hurling aid
from five,sophomore pitchers, including last year's frosh starters
Bill Rock and Richard Spitler.
Sachs also expects batting help
from Catcher Sam Liko and Tony
Salem, who will back up Newton
at first.

Garlock to solve the problem this
year.
Expect Help
Sutherland and Carlock are expected to account for most of the
team's points in the 880-yard run,
while Willoughby will help the
team in the longer events, according to Bridgers.
"One of the better men on the
squad is Ray May," stated Bridgers. "Ray took second place in
the Mason-Dixon Championships
last year in the pole vault. He has
tremendous potential and may
possibly be one of the best pole
vaulters to represent Hopkins."
Caples Looks Good
According to Bridgers, Robin
Caples, a sprinter, has been looking very good in the 220 and 440yard races, and Sam Wright probably be the Jays' top performer
in the discus, shot put, and broad
jump events.
Many of the twenty freshmen
track candidates will be running
in the Intramural Track and Field
Meet which will be held on March
20 and 21. These boys will be
eligible for the meet since they
have not received a major award
in either cross country or track.

Scabbard and Blade, the ROTC
honorary society, recently initiated 25 cadets, according to Richard Small, chairman of the initiations.
Officers of the society will be
elected within the next few weeks,
and the report of an evaluation
committee will be submitted.
Small stated, "A committee has
been appointed to investigate the
areas in which the society can be
of some service to Johns Hopkins.
We feel that participation in university affairs is an obligation df
our membership in Scabbard and
Blade."
The 25 new members are John
Abrams, Tom Brimer, Jim Buddo,
Tom Cox, Ken Daub, Tom Edmonds, Bob Edwards, Eugene
Ewachiw, John Fleischman, John
Gilbert, John Hanst, John Hughes
and Roger Kane.
Also, Henry Kayser, Lew Kirby,
Russ Marcuri, Ray May, Dick
Mercer, Lew Miller, Sid Miller,
Bill Mouring, Martin Rosensweig,
Otto Schroeder, Bill Teso, and
Howard Wisch. Bob Freeman was
pledge master of the group.

Carnegie And The Vandals
The other day some one out outlined to us a possible partial solution to one of the more teasing Homewood paradoxes,
one with which the Student Council is currently wrestling.
The paradox is this: given the assumption that Hopkins
men are communally obligated to act as "gentlemen" and
that therefore they need be curbed with no stated restrictions, what is to be done when occasional abuses of this
absolute liberty tend to create for the outside world the impression that the Hopkins man is not indeed a "gentleman,"
but an unregenerate slob? (Examples: sacking the ROTC
building, some events at fraternity houses, the "brawl"
aspects of some of the gym dances).
The solution suggested to us might be summed up descriptively as "moral suasion." Someone is, let us say, very
offensively and actively blotto at one of the rush dances.
Things are going rapidly downhill. It is then the obligation
of any nearby Student Council member to approach, and
attempt to ameliorate the situation, possibly by •pointing
out that this is conduct prejudicial to the good name of a
"select community of gentlemen and scholars."
Yet it seems to us that it is in the true meaning of this
phrase that the heart of the paradox lies. The Hopkins man
is "select," all right, but only intellectually select; otherwise, he comes from a thousand different environments, each
with its own shade of thinking conduct-wise, each drawing
the line at a different place. Some of us don't drink, others
stop at the happy stage, others foggily call for tomato juice
the next morning. And in such a diversified milieu, who is
to say that any approach is wrong? If there are no stated
limitations, isn't judging our conduct our business?

Of course this is not the whole story. The people we are
with have an important influence on our actions; the trouble
is, group pressure can work both ways, depending on the
situation at the moment. Another point: the campus leaders who are to do the "persuading" we have mentioned, are
leaders because of their disinclination to be a bastard about
things. (There is an old News-Letter proverb: "Nice guys
finish last—except when entry representatives are being
elected.") The phrase "knock it off" carries a certain stigma,
even among gentlemen and scholars.
What it boils down to is this: "moral suasion" can
work—indeed, already does work—up to a point; but it is
as optimistic as it is unfair, in a situation where the standards are left to the individual, to expect it to obviate all
bad publicity for the University, even with all the good
will in the world. If the Hopkins man is to be left free
to develop, it must be expected that there will be development at all levels.

The quickest and most obvious
way to do this is to make money.
This makes people, especially his
boss, think he is EFFICIENT. Who
would suspect that it is not efficiency, but done at the expense of
the quality of the food? However,
if he does just make ends meet,
is there any reason to believe that
he is inefficient or that the quality
of the food is higher? In other
words, he may make money with
good food or bad food; and he
may have good food and make or
not make money. Also, he may
make money and be efficient or'
not efficient, and he may be efficient and make or not make
money.
The reason this paradox exists
is because these terms and standards are without meaning in the

present situation. They are without meaning because we do not
have free consumer choice. This
is the general system of the economy of this country, and traditionally and historically, these
terms have been standards and
measurements until today they
have become accepted as absolute

Well, John, it's hard to define the difference in a way that
will satisfy everybody, because one always finds a lot of overlapping between research and development work. But most
people agree that there are differences, especially in time sequence.Research work comes first, because one of its main objectives is to establish or discover new scientific facts that will
supply the foundation for new industrial developments. In
other .words, research men seek new knowledge about matter, generally working with small quantities of it.
Development work comes later, and Du Pout has two main
types. First, there is new process development. Here scientists
and engineers modify, streamline, and augment the findings
of research so that new chemical products can be profitably
made on a large scale—or existing products can be made by
newer and more efficient methods. Pilot-plant and semi-works
operations are usually included under this heading.
Second, an important kind of development work is directed
toward improvement of existing processes and products. Here
the men study how to obtain yield increases, utilize by-products,increase outputs,and solve sales service problems as they
arise. This may require considerable research, and that brings
us back to the overlapping I previously mentioned.
There are genuine differences, John, but a good deal of
similarity,too—especiallyin the constant need for imagination
and creative effort. I think you'll find that research and development work are equally challenging and rewarding at
Du Pont.

John B.Aaron worked for Du Pont as a summer
laboratory assistant even before he graduated from
Princeton with a B.S. in 1940. After military service he
obtained an M.S.Ch.E. from M.I.T. and returned to
Du Pont in 1947. Over the years he has had many opportunities to observe Du Pont research and development
work. Today John is process and methods supervisor at
the Philadelphia Plant of Du Pont's Fabrics and Finishes Department.

Picked as the dark horse to repeat last year's showing and to
take the match, the Hopkins fencing team travels to Lehigh University tomorrow to compete in
the big event of the season, the
Middle Atlantic Championships.
Five other schools will particiPate in the event. They include
Stephens Institute of Technology,
Mulenberg College, Temple University, Lehigh University, and
Haverford College.

by a six-man

three. John Forte and

both Young

the Middle Atlantics. However.
Schlick is undecided whether to
use him in the foil or the epee.
If he fences in the foil event, then
Mark Zequeira will be the second
man on the epee team. But if
Rose competes in the epee, Fred
Rosenblum will get the nod in the
foil.
Schlick commented, "On the
basis of their showing against us,
Temple and Lehigh will be the
teams to beat. Every man will
have to fence eleven bouts instead

face his own team mate first and
then each man from each of the
other schools in the other ten
bouts."
